back_translation_en: ‘I have a headache,’ lit. ‘I am killed by the head.’
comms_internal: PASS. Ke is the preposition used to flag agent phrases, its etymology is the grammaticalization of a copula. Bolawa derives from bolaya lit. ‘kill’ via passive derivation. Alternative is the same construction with the verb opelwa, derived from opa ‘ache’ via applicative + passive derivation: opa ‘ache’ (intr.) + APPL> opela ‘ache for someone’ (tr.) + PASS > opelwa ‘be a person for whom some bodypart aches’ (intr.). Cf. “Ke opelwa ke tlhogo” = “ke-op-el-w-a ke Ø-tlhogo” [sI:1SG-ache.APPL-PASS-FV by SG-head(9)] ‘I have a headache.’ lit. ‘I am ached.for by the head.’

back_translation_en: ‘You might catch this illness.’ lit. ‘You might be entered by this illness.’
comms_internal: PASS. Tsenwa derives from tsena ‘enter’ via passive derivation.
sentence_original_orthography: O ka tsenwa ke bolwetse jo.

back_translation_en: ‘The child is afraid of the dog.’
comms_internal: The verb tshaba is also used intransitively with the meaning ‘run away’. Cf. “Legodu le tshabile.” = “le-godu le-tshab-il-e” [SG-thief(5) sI:cl5-run.away-PRF-FV] ‘The thief ran away.’

Same as 86. The same verb in the same construction can also mean ‘abandon’, depending on the nature of the object, cf. “Kitso o latlhile mosadi wa gagwe.” = “Kitso o-latlh-il-e mo-sadi wa-gagwe” [PRN(1) sI:cl1-throw-PRF-FV SG-woman(1) cl1.GEN-cl1.PRO] ‘Kitso abandoned his wife.’

back_translation_en: ‘I have enough money.’ lit. ‘The money suffices (for) me.’
comms_internal: The verb lekana (which also means ‘suit’) is used intransitively with a plural subject means ‘be equal’, ‘be equivalent’. Cf. “Re a lekana” = “re-a-lekan-a” [sI:1PL-DJ-be.equal-FV] ‘We are equal.’

le is a comitative proclitic, also used for noun coordination (‘and’). This coding frame is general for the bivalent verbs whose arguments can be switched without changing the denotative meaning, cf. also (11), (23), (24), (32), (64), (94), (98).

This verb can also mean ‘accept’, cf.: “Puso e tlaa dumela kopo ya motse.” = “Ø-puso e-tlaa-dumel-a Ø-kopo ya-mo-tse” [SG-government(9) sI:cl9-FUT-accept-FV SG-request(9) cl9.GEN-SG-village(3)] ‘The government will accept the request of the village.’

back_translation_en: ‘I took the book from the table.’
comms_internal: The verb tsaya is transitive. It has an irregular perfect form: tsere.
Same as 55. This is a transitive construction with the perceiver in subject role.
Same as 22. This is a transitive construction.
This is the intransitive construction commonly found with the bivalent verbs that can switch their arguments without changing the denotative meaning.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke kopane le Kitso mo mmileng.

comms_internal: This is an intransitive construction.
fenya ‘defeat, beat’ is transitive.

back_translation_en: ‘The man got out of the car.’
comms_internal: This is an intransitive construction. The perfect of tswa (dule) is irregular.

back_translation_en: ‘I drove the cows to the kraal.’
comms_internal: The verb kgweetsa is a transitive verb whose general meaning is ‘drive’.
The verb koba ‘bend’ is transitive.

back_translation_en: ‘S/he told me that the child was lying.’
comms_internal: Tswana has a quotative verb re ‘say’ that introduces reported utterances but is incompatible with the expression of the addressee. Its infinitive gore is used as a complementizer with the other verbs of speech. bolelela and its synonym raya are transitive verbs whose object represents the addressee. bolelela is the applicative form of bolela ‘tell’. Alternative is the same construction with raya. “O ntheile gore ngwana o buile maaka.” = “o-n-the-il-e gore ngw-ana o-bu-il-e ma-aka” [sI:cl1-oI:1SG-tell-PRF-FV that SG-child(1) sI:cl1-tell-PRF-FV PL-lie(6)] ‘S/he told me that the child was lying.’. raya is probably cognate with the quotative verb re, but there is no regular morphological process that could derive raya from re.
sentence_original_orthography: O mpoleletse gore ngwana o buile maaka.

back_translation_en: ‘The child is holding a book in his hands.’
comms_internal: In Tswana, ‘hold’ is expressed as the perfect of the transitive verb tshwara ‘catch’. ka is an instrumental preposition.
sentence_original_orthography: Ngwana o tshwere buka ka diatla.

back_translation_en: ‘S/he caught me up on the road.’
comms_internal: The general meaning of the transitive verb tshwara is ‘catch’, cf. also (18).
The verb gama ‘milk’ is transitive.
fitlha ‘reach, arrive’ is intransitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Mokoro o fitlhile ko lotshitshing lwa lewatle.

comms_internal: Same as 10. The verb ama ‘touch’ is transitive.

back_translation_en: ‘The cat is fighting with a dog.’
comms_internal: This is the intransitive construction commonly found with the bivalent verbs that can switch their arguments without changing the denotative meaning.
tsalana derives from the noun tsala ‘friend’. Its coding frame is the coding frame typical for the bivalent verbs that can switch their arguments without changing the denotative meaning.
This is an intransitive construction. The basic meaning of the preposition ka is instrumental.
Same as 100.
The verb gadika ‘fry’ is transitive.
The transitive verb emela ‘wait for’ is etymologically the applicative verb derived from intransitive ema ‘stand’.

sentence: fa mo-tho a-batl-a se-ngwe o-lebal-a di-kotsi
glosses_en: when SG-person(1) sI:cl1-want-FV cl7-INDEF sI:cl1-forget-FV PL-danger(8/10)
back_translation_en: ‘When you want something you forget the dangers.’
comms_internal: The verb lebala ‘forget’ is transitive. The distinction similar to that between forget sth. vs. forget about sth. is sometimes specified by means of the preposition ka ga ‘about’, but it is more common to have the same transitive construction indiscriminately. DC suspects that the construction with a preposition might be a calque of the English construction. Cf. also: “Ga ke a lebala ditaelo” = “ga-ke-a-lebal-a di-taelo” [NEG-sI:1SG-PRF.NEG-forget-FV PL-instruction(8/10)] ‘I didn’t forget the instructions’.
sentence_original_orthography: Fa motho a batla sengwe, o lebala dikotsi.

comms_internal: The verb laolwa is the passive form of laola ‘order’. Alternative is the construction with the verb ikaega, which is etymologically the reflexive form of aega ‘lean’, and the SBJ_ka pattern, cf. “Tshwetso e ikaegile ka wena” = “Ø-tshwetso e-i-kaeg-il-e ka wena” [SG-decision(9) sI:cl9-REFL-lean-PRF-FV INS 2SG.PRO] ‘The decision depends on you.’
The verb bitsa ‘call’ is transitive.
The intransitive reciprocal verb tlwaelana derives from transitive tlwaela ‘get accostumed to’
sentence_original_orthography: Ke tlwaelane le monna wa gagwe.

comms_internal: The verb itse ‘know’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Ga ke itse monna wa gagwe.

comms_internal: The transitive verb letsa is the causative verb derived from intransitive lela ‘cry, sound’.
The verb tila ‘avoid’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: O tshwanetse go tila ditsala tse di bosula.

comms_internal: The verb dira ‘make’ (also ‘do’) is transitive.

back_translation_en: ‘You would do better not to make fun of them.’
comms_internal: This is a transitive construction, but tshega is also used intransitively with the meaning ‘laugh’, cf. “Re tshega thata e bile re itumelela botshelo.” = “re-tsheg-a thata ebile re-itumelel-a bo-tshelo” [sI:1PL-laugh-FV much and sI:1PL-enjoy-FV SG-life(14)] ‘We laugh a lot and enjoy life.’
sentence_original_orthography: O se ka wa ba tshega.

comms_internal: The verb na ‘have’ is defective and morphologically irregular, and has unique syntactic properties, and there is no obvious explanation for that, cf. Creissels (2024a). In some tenses, the possessee phrase is obligatorily flagged by the comitative proclitic le, whereas in some other tenses, the possessee phrase is not flagged. However, even when it is not flagged, the possessee phrase cannot be indexed on the verb, and consequeltly does not behave as an object. An example where no flag is used: “Mpho ga a na koloi.” = “Mpho ga-a-na Ø-koloi” [PRN(1) have SG-car(9)] ‘Mpho doesn’t have a car.’
Same as 121. The verb batla ‘look for’ (and also ‘need’, ‘ask for’, ‘want’) is transitive.
The verb penta ‘paint’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Kitso o pentile ntlo ya gagwe..

comms_internal: The verb loma ‘bite’ is transitive.

This is a passive (intransitive) construction. The derivation is as follows: X latlh-a Y ‘X throws/abandons Y’ (transitive) cf. (4) + decausative > Y latlh-eg-a ‘Y gets lost’ (intransitive)’ + applicative > Y latlh-eg-el-a Z ‘Y gets lost for Z’ (transitive) + passive > Z latlh-eg-el-w-a ke Y) ‘Z is affected by the loss of Y’ (intransitive)’. Alternative is the verb “amogwa”, used in the transitive construction, cf. “Ke amogilwe dithoto tsa me.” = “ke-amog-il-w-e di-thoto tsa-me” [sI:1SG-take.from-PRF-PASS-FV PL-property(8/10) cl8/10.GEN-1SG.PRO] ‘I have been stripped of my property.’ This is a transitive construction resulting from passivization of a ditransitive verb (in Tswana, any of the two objects of ditransitive verbs can be converted into the subject of a passive construction, the other object being maintained in object role): Z amoga X Y ‘Z takes Y from X’ > X amogwa Y (ke X) ‘X is deprived of T (by Z)
sentence_original_orthography: Ke latlhegetswe ke ntlo ya me.

back_translation_en: ‘The policeman is trying to catch the thief.’
comms_internal: CV. The verb tshwara ‘catch’ is transitive. The aspectual meaning ‘try to catch’ (as in the Russian example) could only be expressed periphrastically, by combining thwara ‘catch’ with the verb leka ‘try’.
sentence_original_orthography: Lepodisi le leka go tshwara legodu.

comms_internal: The Tswana verb thuba ‘break’ is transitive. Intransitive ‘break’ is rendered as thubega (decausative derivation).

comms: Not included in the database because the translation deviates too far from the stimulus sentence.
comms_internal: DC: I was not able to find an exact equivalent of ‘flatter’, but only near equivalents: boka ‘praise’ and fora ‘deceive’. Both are transitive. Cf. the construction with the latter verb: “Ba re forile.” = “ba-re-for-il-e” [sI:cl2-oI:1PL-trick-PRF-FV] ‘They tricked us.’

The verb tshikinya ‘shake, wave’ is transitive. Although this particular example is different from the questionnaire sentence, the same verb is used in the transitive construction with a broad spectrum of usages, including ‘Magnets can move iron’, ‘Revolutions rocked Eastern Europe in 1989’, etc.

sentence: Kitso o-lor-a ka Ø-koloi e n-tšha
glosses_en: PRN(1) sI:cl1-dream-FV INS SG-car(9) c9.LK cl9-new
back_translation_en: ‘Kitso is dreaming of a new car.’
comms_internal: Same verb as in 97, different pattern. The verb lora ‘dream’ can be used transitively, or intransitively with a complement flagged by the instrumental preposition ka. The transitive construction seems to be preferred when lora is taken in its literal meaning, cf. (97), and the intransitive construction when lora means ‘long for’, but this is not a strict rule.
sentence_original_orthography: Kitso o lora ka koloi e ntšha.

comms_internal: The verb tlhatswa ‘wash’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke tlaa tlhatswa diaparo tsa me kamoso.

comms_internal: The verb apara ‘put on (clothes)’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke tlaa apara diaparo tse dingwe

comms_internal: The verb bidiwa is the passive form of bitsa ‘call’ (transitive). In this construction, bidiwa is followed by an unflagged noun which however does not behave as an object in other respects.
The verb otlhaya ‘punish’ is transitive.
The verb tlhasela ‘attack’ is transitive.

back_translation_en: ‘(With the rain,) the hole could get filled with water.’
comms_internal: The verb tlala ‘get filled’ is intransitive. The verb tlatsa (tr.) ‘fill’ derives from tlala via causative derivation.
sentence_original_orthography: Khuti e ka tlala ka metsi.

comms_internal: Same as 9.
‘Pula’ is the Botswanan currency):
The verb tlhoa ‘hate’ is transitive.
Same as (56).

The verb dikaganyetsa ‘surround’ is transitive. It is cognate with dika ‘encircle’ (also transitive), but the relationship between these two verbs cannot be accounted for in terms of synchronically productive derivational processes.

This is a passive construction. The verb salelwa results from the following derivation: sala ‘remain (intr.)’+ APPL > salela ‘remain for someone’ (tr.) + PASS > salelwa ‘be a person for whom something remains (intr.)
The verb araba ‘answer’ is transitive.
The verb bula ‘open’ is transitive. Intransitive ‘open’ (bulega) is formed via decausative derivation.
This is the intransitive construction typical for bivalent verbs whose arguments can switch without affecting the denotative meaning.
sentence_original_orthography: Koloi ya me e farologane le ya gago.

comms_internal: CV. The transitive verb salela derives from intransitive sala ‘remain’ via applicative derivation. morago is an adverb (Tswana doesn’t have postpositions).
The verb lema ‘plough’ is transitive.
The verb nkga alone means ‘emit a strong odor’. The NP that follows it is not a real object, rather an unflagged oblique.
The verb kgabaganya ‘cross’ is transitive.
The verb opela ‘sing’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: O opetse pina e e monate.

comms_internal: The verb kwala ‘write’ is transitive.

The verb nwa ‘drink’ is transitive, but it also has an intransitive use with the meaning ‘be absorbed’, cf. “Bolo e nole.” = “Ø-ball(9) e-no-l-e” [SG-ball(9) sI:cl9-be.absorbed-PRF-FV] ‘The ball scored / went into the goal.’
The transitive verb gakolosa is a causative verb deriving from intransitive gakologa.

sentence_original_orthography: Lebanta le le tsamaelana le pmosese wa me.

comms_internal: The transitive verb tlogela ‘abandon’ derives from intransitive tloga ‘go away’ (reversive from tla ‘come’) via applicative derivation.
sentence_original_orthography: Batho ba ba tlogetse legae la gagwe.

comms_internal: Formally, the verbs khurumetsa ‘cover (in general)’ and khurumela ‘cover with a lid’(as in khurumela maši ‘cover the milk’) seem to be related via causative derivation, but they are equally transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Letsela la tafole le khurumetsa tafole.

comms_internal: The transitive verb gopola ‘remember’ also expresses the more general meaning ‘think about something, consider’.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke gopola ntlo ya batsadi ba me.

comms_internal: The verb thusa ‘help’ is transitive.
The verb tlhaloganya ‘understand’ is transitive.

The intransitive verb wela ‘fal into/onto’ derives from wa ‘fall’. In Tswana, licensing locative expressions that specify direction of movement is one of the functions of applicative derivation, and in this function, applicative derivation does not transitivize intransitive verbs (Creissels 2024b).
The verb kgaola ‘cut’ is transitive, but the reflexive prefix saturates the object valency.

back_translation_en: ‘A chewing gum got stuck to my shoe.’
comms_internal: The verb kgomarela ‘get stuck to’ is transitive.
sentence_original_orthography: Chewing-gum e kgomaretse setlhako sa me.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: There doesn’t seem to exist an exact equivalent of X lost to Y in Tswana. This meaning is expressed as Y beat X, cf. (13).
Same as 120.

The verb bua ‘speak’ can be used intransitively, or transitively with an object referring to speech (as in bua maaka ‘tell lies’). An alternative for this entry is the transitive verb buisa ‘address someone’, derived from bua ‘speak’ via causative derivation. It can be viewed as an instance of sociative causation, cf. “Kitso o buisitse Mpho.” = “Kitso o-bu-is-its-e Mpho” [PRN(1) sI:cl1-speak-CAUS-PRF-FV PRN(1)] ‘Kitso engaged in conversation with Mpho’
The basic meaning of the transitive verb tshola ‘give birth to’ is ‘bear’. Its passive form tsholwa is used with the meaning ‘be born’.
sentence_original_orthography: Dimpho o tshotse bana bale batlhano.

comms_internal: Same as 4. The general meaning of the transitive verb latlha is ‘throw, abandon’. In this example, the use of the applicative form is necessary to license the locative complement ‘on the ground’ referring to direction of movement.
The transitive verb tsamaisa is a causative verb derived from intransitive tsamaya ‘walk, go, work’.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke Kitso o tsamaisang mokgatlho wa rona.

comms_internal: The verb tlhologela ‘miss’ is transitive.
The verb latela ‘follow’ is transitive.
The verb fologa ‘get down from’ is transitive.
The verb reetsa ‘listen’ is transitive
Same as 93.
sentence_original_orthography: Bana ba tshwanetse go utlwa batsadi ba bone.

comms_internal: Same as 92.

back_translation_en: ‘The honey got mixed with the milk.’
comms_internal: The transitive verb tlhakana ‘get mixed’ has the coding frame typical for the bivalent verbs whose arguments can be switched without changing the denotative meaning. Causative derivation from tlhakana yields tlhakanya (tr.) ‘mix’, and applicative derivation yields tlhakanela (tr.) ‘share’.
The verb apola ‘take off’ (cognate with apara ‘put on’) is transitive.

Same verb as in 48, different pattern. The verb lora ‘dream’ can be used transitively, or intransitively with a complement flagged by the instrumental preposition ka. The transitive construction seems to be preferred when lora is taken in its literal meaning, and the intransitive construction when lora means ‘long for’, cf. (48), but this is not a strict rule.
The intransitive verb dumalana ‘agree’ derives from transitive dumela ‘accept, believe’ via reciprocal derivation.

back_translation_en: ‘The woman is arguing with her husband.’
comms_internal: The verb ngangisana ‘argue with someone’ results from the following derivation: nganga ‘debate’ (intr.) + CAUS > ngangisa ‘initiate a debate with someone’ (tr.) + REC > ngangisana ‘argue with someone’ (tr.)
sentence_original_orthography: Mosadi o ngangisana le monna wa gagwe.

comms_internal: Same as 26. The basic meaning of the transitive verb ja ‘cost’ is ‘eat’, cf. (26).
sentence_original_orthography: Tshupanako ya gago e ja bokae?

sentence: mo-tsomi o-ne a-hul-a Ø-tau mme a-e-fos-a
glosses_en: SG-hunter(1) sI:cl1-PST sI:cl1-shoot-FV SG-lion(9) but sI:cl1-oI:cl9-miss-FV
back_translation_en: ‘The hunter shot at the lion but he missed it.’
sentence_original_orthography: Motsomi o ne a hula tau mme a e fosa.

comms_internal: The verb tshela ‘pour’ is transitive.

This is a passive construction resulting from the following derivation: latlha ‘throw, abandon’ (tr.) + DECAUS > latlhega ‘get lost’ (intr.) + APPL > latlhegela ‘get lost for someone’ (tr.) + PASS > latlhegelwa ‘be affected by the loss of’ (intr.)

The verb nwela is the applicative verb derived from nwa ‘get absorbed’ (identical to ‘drink’, cf. (71)). In this example, applicative derivation licenses a locative expression denoting direction of movement, but has no transitivizing effect.
The verb bolaya ‘kill’ is transitive.
The verb thula ‘hit’ is transitive.
The verb suna ‘kiss’ is transitive.
The transitive verb bala co-expresses ‘read’ and ‘count’.
The verb tshikinya ‘move’ is a transitive verb, from which tshikinyega ‘move (intr.)’ derives via decausative derivation.
sentence_original_orthography: A o ka tshikinya ditsebe tsa gago?

comms_internal: The verbs tlotla ‘respect’ is transitive. The intransitive verb tlotlega ‘be worth of respect’ can be formed from it via decausative derivation.
sentence_original_orthography: O tshwanetse go tlotla bagolwane ba gago.

comms_internal: This is a passive construction. The verb tenwa ‘be disgusted by’ derives from transitive tena ‘disgust’ via passive derivation. Cf. also (128)
sentence_original_orthography: Ke tenwa ke dipoleiti tse di leswe.

comms_internal: The transitive verb kgotsofalela ‘be satisfied with’ derives from intransitive kgotsofala ‘be satisfied’ via applicative derivation. The transitive verb kgotsofatsa ‘satisfy’ also derives from kgotsofala ‘be satisfied’, via causative derivation. The verb kgotsofala can combine with an adverbial clause denoting the cause of satisfaction (cf. “Ke a fgotsofala fa ke kgona go thusa batho.” = “ke-a-kgotsofal-a fa ke-kgon-a go-thus-a ba-tho” [sI:1SG-DJ-be.satisfied-FV when sI:1SG-be.able-FV INF-help-FV PL-person(2)] ‘I am happy when I am able to help people.’), but applicative derivation is necessary to license an object NP.
sentence_original_orthography: Mpho o kgotsofaletse ngwana wa gagwe.

comms: No satisfactory translation has been obtained.
comms_internal: Tswana has a transitive verb rata ‘love’ (see 46), but the aspectual distinction between ‘love’ and ‘fall in love’ can only be rendered periphrastically, for example go simolola go nna le maikutlo ‘begin to experience feelings’.

Alternative is tshepa. Both tshepa and ikanya are transitive. Tshepa also means ‘hope’, whereas ikanya only means ‘trust’. Ikanya is formally a reflexive verb, but its etymology is unclear, since it has no non-reflexive counterpart; I can only say that it is probably cognate with ana ‘revere’ and ikana ‘swear’.
sentence_original_orthography: Ngwana o tshwanetse go ikanya batsadi ba gagwe.

comms_internal: CV. In Tswana, ‘X feels pity’ is expressed as X tlhomoga pelo, where pelo is the noun meaning ‘heart’, and tlhomoga is a verb that seems to exist only in combination with pelo. Applicative derivation gives rise to X tlhomogela Y pelo ‘X feels pity for Y’, where Y is the object of the applicative verb tlhomogela. The verb tlhomoga exists only in combination with pelo ‘heart’, and in this combination, pelo does not behave as the head of a noun phrase acting as a nominal term of the clause: it cannot be deleted, it cannot take modifiers, it cannot be either topicalized or focalized, etc. etc. The combination tlhomoga + pelo is completely lexicalized, and it would not make sense to analyze pelo as fulfilling a syntactic role. The only possible analysis that comes to my mind is to characterize pelo as a frozen object that combines with a verb that has no independent existence into a monovalent predicate. In sentences like “Ke tlhomogela mosadi yo pelo”, “mosadi yo” ‘this woman’ has all the properties of an object NP, whereas pelo has the appearance (but only the appearance) of the second object in a double-object construction.

The transitive verb fufegela ‘envy’ derives from intransitive fufega ‘be envious’ via applicative derivation. The intransitive verb fufega does not allow to mention the second person (the one being envied) at all. This is a general property of Tswana applicatives. In general, Tswana applicatives are not optional applicatives (i.e., applicatives making it possible to encode as objects participants that otherwise could be coded as obliques), but obligatory applicatives (i.e. applicatives making it possible to express participants that could not be expressed at all in a clause projected by the non-applicative form of the verb), cf. my chapter on Tswana applicatives in the applicative volume edited by Fernando Zúñiga and myself.
sentence_original_orthography: Mpho o fufegela tsala ya gagwe.

comms_internal: Same as 122. The transitive verb galefela is an applicative verb derived from the intransitive verb galefa ‘be angry’. The transitive verb galefisa ‘make angry’ also derives from galefa ‘be angry’, via causative derivation. The verb galefa cannot be used with an overt NP denoting the person who is the stimulus/cause of the emotion.
sentence_original_orthography: Mpho o galefetse tsala ya gagwe.

comms_internal: PASS. Same as 125. The derivational path is as follows: gakgamala ‘be surprised’ (intr.) + CAUS > gakgamatsa ‘surprise (tr.) + PASS > gakgamadiwa ‘be surprised by something ‘(intr.)
Same as 83.
sentence_original_orthography: Ke itumelela tee e e monate.

comms_internal: Same as 39.

back_translation_en: ‘The woman is angry with the children.’
comms_internal: Same as 117. The transitive verb galefela is an applicative verb derived from the intransitive verb galefa ‘be angry’. The transitive verb galefisa ‘make angry’ also derives from galefa ‘be angry’, via causative derivation. The verb galefa cannot be used with an overt NP denoting the person who is the stimulus/cause of the emotion.
The transitive verb kgopisegela results from the following derivational path: kgopisa ‘offend’ (tr.) + DECAUS > kgopisega ‘take offence’ (intr.) + APPL > kgopisegela ‘take offence about (tr.)

CV. In Tswana, ‘be sad’ is expressed as utlwa botlhoko ‘feel bitterness/pain’, also used for physical pain. Causative derivation yields utlwisa botlhoko, literally ‘make feel bitterness/pain’. The CV “utlwa botlhoko” ‘feel bitterness/pain’ is a transitive construction, and causative derivation converts it into a double-object constrcution.
sentence_original_orthography: Mafoko a gago a utlwisitse Kitso botlhoko.

comms_internal: PASS. Same as 118. The derivational path is as follows: gakgamala ‘be surprised’ (intr.) + CAUS > gakgamatsa ‘surprise (tr.) + PASS > gakgamadiwa ‘be surprised by something ‘(intr.)
The verb nyatsa ‘despise’ is transitive. Decausative derivation yields nyatsega ‘be despicable’.
The intransitive verb tshwenyega ‘worry (intr.)’ derives from transitive tshwenya ‘worry (tr.)’ via decausative derivation.

The transitive verb tenegela results from the following derivational path: tena ‘disgust, irritate’ (tr.) + DECAUS > tenega ‘get irritated’ (intr.) + APPL > tenegela ‘get irritated about’ (tr.). Cf. also (111).

sentence: Kitso o-tlhab-iw-a ke di-tlhong ka se-emo sa-gagwe se se-nnye
glosses_en: PRN(1) sI:cl1-stab-PASS-FV by PL-shame(8/10) INS SG-stature(7) cl7.GEN-cl1.PRO cl7-LK cl7-small
back_translation_en: ‘Kitso is ashamed of his small stature.’
comms_internal: CV. The literal meaning of X tlhabiwa ke ditlhong ka Y is ‘X is stabbed by shame about Y’. The verb tlhaba ‘pierce, stab’ is transitive, and tlhabiwa is formed from it via passive derivation. There is no other way to express ‘be ashamed’ in Tswana.
sentence_original_orthography: Kitso o tlhabiwa ke ditlhong ka seemo sa gagwe se sennye.
